query: What are the 17 plane-group symmetries used in crystalline packing for 2D polygon optimization?

results.title: ANSWER
results.text:
The 17 crystallographic plane‑group (wallpaper) symmetries that can be used to tile the plane – and therefore to build the densest packings of regular polygons in two dimensions – are the classic two‑dimensional space groups classified by the International Union of Crystallography.  They are grouped according to the shape of the Bravais lattice of the unit cell:

* **Oblique lattice** – p1, p2  
* **Rectangular lattice** – pm, pg, cm, p2 mm, p2 mg, p2 gg, c2 mm  
* **Square lattice** – p4, p4 mm, p4 gm  
* **Hexagonal (triangular) lattice** – p3, p3 m1, p31 m, p6, p6 mm  

These symbols (e.g., *p1*, *p2mm*, *p4gm*, *p6mm*) are the International (Hermann‑Mauguin) notations for the 17 plane groups that exhaust all possible combinations of translations, rotations (2‑, 3‑, 4‑, 6‑fold), mirrors and glide‑mirrors in a periodic 2‑D pattern ([it.iucr.org](https://it.iucr.org/Ac/ch2o2v0001)) and are reproduced in many crystallography references ([clarku.edu](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/seventeen.html)).

results.title: the 17 plane symmetry groups
results.text:
[![](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/logo.gif)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/index.html) # The 17 plane symmetry groups The various planar patterns can by classified by the transformation groups that leave them invariant, their symmetry groups. A mathematical analysis of these groups shows that there are exactly 17 different plane symmetry groups. Note that clicking on a small image below will take you to a discussion of the associated symmetry group (as will selecting the name of the group in the headings below). * * * ![](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wallindex.gif) ### A short table of characteristics of the symmetry groups There are enough characteristics listed in the table to distinguish the 17 different groups. | Symmetry
group | IUC
notation | Lattice
type | Rotation
orders | Reflection
axes | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | 1 | p1 | parallelogrammatic | none | none | | 2 | p2 | parallelogrammatic | 2 | none | | 3 | pm | rectangle | none | parallel | | 4 | pg | rectangle | none | none | | 5 | cm | rhombus | none | parallel | | 6 | pmm | rectangle | 2 | 90° | | 7 | pmg | rectangle | 2 | parallel | | 8 | pgg | rectangle | 2 | none | | 9 | cmm | rhombus | 2 | 90° | | 10 | p4 | square | 4 | none | | 11 | p4m | square | 4 + | 45° | | 12 | p4g | square | 4 \* | 90° | | 13 | p3 | hexagon | 3 | none | | 14 | p31m | hexagon | 3 \* | 60° | | 15 | p3m1 | hexagon | 3 + | 30° | | 16 | p6 | hexagon | 6 | none | | 17 | p6m | hexagon | 6 | 30° | | | \+ = all rotation centers lie on reflection axes
\\* = not all rotation centers on reflection axes | * * * The IUC notation is the notation for the symmetry group adopted by the International Union of Crystallography in 1952. #### [Symmetry group 1 (p1)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall1.html) This is the simplest symmetry group. It consists only of translations. There are neither reflections, glide-reflections, nor rotations. The two translation axes may be inclined at any angle to each other. Its lattice is parallelogrammatic, so a fundamental region for the symmetry group is the same as that for the translation group, namely, a parallelogram. #### [Symmetry group 2 (p2)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall2.html) This group differs only from the first group in that it contains 180° rotations, that is, rotations of order 2. As in all symmetry groups there are translations, but there neither reflections nor glide reflections. The two translations axes may be inclined at any angle to each other. The lattice is a parallelogrammatic. A fundamental region for the symmetry group is half of a parallelogram that is a fundamental region for the translation group. #### [Symmetry group 3 (pm)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall3.html) This is the first group that contains reflections. The axes of reflection are parallel to one axis of translation and perpendicular to the other axis of translation. The lattice is rectangular. There are neither rotations nor glide reflections. A fundamental region for the translation group is a rectangle, and one can be chosen that is split by an axis of reflection so that one of the half rectangles forms a fundamental region for the symmetry group. #### [Symmetry group 4 (pg)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall4.html) This is the first group that contains glide reflections. The direction of the glide reflection is parallel to one axis of translation and perpendicular to the other axis of translation. There are neither rotations nor reflections. The lattice is rectanglular, and a rectangular fundamental region for the translation group can be chosen that is split by an axis of a glide reflection so that one of the half rectangles forms a fundamental region for the symmetry group. #### [Symmetry group 5 (cm)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall5.html) This group contains reflections and glide reflections with parallel axes. There are no rotations in this group. The translations may be inclined at any angle to each other, but the axes of the reflections bisect the angle formed by the translations, so the fundamental region for the translation group is a rhombus. A fundamental region for the symmetry group is half the rhombus. #### [Symmetry group 6 (pmm)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall6.html) This symmetry group contains perpendicular axes of reflection. There are no glide-reflections or rotations. The lattice is rectanglular, and a rectangle can be chosen for the fundamental region of the translation group so that a quarter-rectangle of it is a fundamental region for the symmetry group. #### [Symmetry group 7 (pmg)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall7.html) This group contains both a reflection and a rotation of order 2. The centers of rotations do not lie on the axes of reflection. The lattice is rectangular, and a quarter-rectangle of a fundamental region for the translation group is a fundamental region for the symmetry group. #### [Symmetry group 8 (pgg)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall8.html) This group contains no reflections, but it has glide-reflections and half-turns. There are perpendicular axes for the glide reflections, and the centers of the rotations do not lie on these axes. Again, the lattice is rectangular, and a quarter-rectangle of a fundamental region for the translation group is a fundamental region for the symmetry group. #### [Symmetry group 9 (cmm)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall9.html) This group has perpendicular reflection axes, as does group 6(pmm), but it also has rotations of order 2. The centers of the rotations do not lie on the reflection axes. The lattice is rhomic, and a quarter of a fundamental region for the translation group is a fundamental region for the symmetry group. #### [Symmetry group 10 (p4)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall10.html) This is the first group with a 90° rotation, that is, a rotation of order 4. It also has rotations of order 2. The centers of the order-2 rotations are midway between the centers of the order-4 rotations. There are no reflections. The lattice is square, and again, a quarter of a fundamental region for the translation group is a fundamental region for the symmetry group. #### [Symmetry group 11 (p4m)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall11.html) This group differs from 10 (p4) in that it also has reflections. The axes of reflection are inclined to each other by 45° so that four axes of reflection pass through the centers of the order-4 rotations. In fact, all the rotation centers lie on the reflection axes. The lattice is square, and an eighth, a triangle, of a fundamental region for the translation group is a fundamental region for the symmetry group. #### [Symmetry group 12 (p4g)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall12.html) This group also contains reflections and rotations of orders 2 and 4. But the axes of reflection are perpendicular, and none of the rotation centers lie on the reflection axes. Again, the lattice is square, and an eighth of a square fundamental region of the translation group is a fundamental region for the symmetry group. #### [Symmetry group 13 (p3)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall13.html) This is the simplest group that contains a 120°-rotation, that is, a rotation of order 3, and the first one whose lattice is hexagonal. #### [Symmetry group 14 (p31m)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall14.html) This group contains reflections (whose axes are inclined at 60° to one another) and rotations of order 3. Some of the centers of rotation lie on the reflection axes, and some do not. The lattice is hexagonal. #### [Symmetry group 15 (p3m1)](https://www2.clarku.edu/faculty/djoyce/wallpaper/wall15.html) This group...

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
This article summarizes the classes of[discrete](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_space)[symmetry groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_group)of the[Euclidean plane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_plane). The symmetry groups are named here by three naming schemes:[International notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermann%E2%80%93Mauguin_notation),[orbifold notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbifold_notation), and[Coxeter notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coxeter_notation).
There are three kinds of symmetry groups of the plane:
* 2 families of[rosette groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosette_groups)– 2D[point groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point_group#Two_dimensions)
* 7[frieze groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frieze_group)– 2D[line groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_group#Two-dimensional)
* 17[wallpaper groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallpaper_group)– 2D[space groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_group).
## Rosette groups
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_planar_symmetry_groups&action=edit&section=1)]
There are two families of discrete two-dimensional point groups, and they are specified with parameter*n*, which is the order of the group of the rotations in the group.

## Frieze groups
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_planar_symmetry_groups&action=edit&section=2)]
The 7[frieze groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frieze_group), the two-dimensional[line groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_group), with a direction of periodicity are given with five notational names. The[Schönflies notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sch%C3%B6nflies_notation)is given as infinite limits of 7 dihedral groups. The yellow regions represent the infinite fundamental domain in each.

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Classification of a two-dimensional repetitive pattern
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Wallpaper_group-p4m-5.jpg/250px-Wallpaper_group-p4m-5.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wallpaper_group-p4m-5.jpg)Example of an[Egyptian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt)design with wallpaper group[***p*4*m***](#Group_p4mm)
A**wallpaper group**(or**plane symmetry group**or**plane crystallographic group**) is a mathematical classification of a two-dimensional repetitive pattern, based on the[symmetries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry)in the pattern. Such patterns occur frequently in[architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture)and[decorative art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decorative_art), especially in[textiles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Textile),[tiles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tile), and[wallpaper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallpaper).
The simplest wallpaper group, Group*p*1, applies when there is no symmetry beyond simple translation of a pattern in two dimensions. The following patterns have more forms of symmetry, including some rotational and reflectional symmetries:
* [![Example A: Cloth, Tahiti](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Wallpaper_group-p4m-2.jpg/120px-Wallpaper_group-p4m-2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wallpaper_group-p4m-2.jpg)
Example**A**: Cloth,[Tahiti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tahiti)
* [![Example B: Ornamental painting, Nineveh, Assyria](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Wallpaper_group-p4m-1.jpg/120px-Wallpaper_group-p4m-1.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wallpaper_group-p4m-1.jpg)
Example**B**: Ornamental painting,[Nineveh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nineveh),[Assyria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assyria)
* [![Example C: Painted porcelain, China](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Wallpaper_group-p4g-2.jpg/120px-Wallpaper_group-p4g-2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wallpaper_group-p4g-2.jpg)
Example**C**: Painted[porcelain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porcelain),[China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China)
Examples**A**and**B**have the same wallpaper group; it is called[***p*4*m***](#Group_p4mm)in the[IUCr notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Union_of_Crystallography#IUCr_Symmetry_notation)and[\*442](#Group_p4mm)in the[orbifold notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbifold_notation). Example**C**has a different wallpaper group, called[***p*4*g***](#Group_p4gm)or[4\*2](#Group_p4gm). The fact that**A**and**B**have the same wallpaper group means that they have the same symmetries, regardless of the designs' superficial details; whereas**C**has a different set of symmetries.
The number of symmetry groups depends on the number of dimensions in the patterns. Wallpaper groups apply to the two-dimensional case, intermediate in complexity between the simpler[frieze groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frieze_group)and the three-dimensional[space groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_group).
A[proof](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_proof)that there are only 17 distinct[groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_(mathematics))of such planar symmetries was first carried out by[Evgraf Fedorov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yevgraf_Fyodorov)in 1891[[1]](#cite_note-1)and then derived independently by[George Pólya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_P%C3%B3lya)in 1924.[[2]](#cite_note-2)The proof that the list of wallpaper groups is complete came only after the much harder case of[space groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_group)had been done. The seventeen wallpaper groups are listed below; see[§ The seventeen groups](#The_seventeen_groups).
## Symmetries of patterns
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wallpaper_group&action=edit&section=1)]
A[symmetry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry)of a pattern is, loosely speaking, a way of transforming the pattern so that it looks exactly the same after the transformation. For example,[translational symmetry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Translational_symmetry)is present when the pattern can be[translated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Translation_(geometry))(in other words, shifted) some finite distance and appear unchanged. Think of shifting a set of vertical stripes horizontally by one stripe. The pattern is unchanged. Strictly speaking, a true symmetry only exists in patterns that repeat exactly and continue indefinitely. A set of only, say, five stripes does not have translational symmetry—when shifted, the stripe on one end "disappears" and a new stripe is "added" at the other end. In practice, however, classification is applied to finite patterns, and small imperfections may be ignored.
The types of transformations that are relevant here are called[Euclidean plane isometries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_plane_isometry). For example:
* If one*shifts*example**B**one unit to the right, so that each square covers the square that was originally adjacent to it, then the resulting pattern is*exactly the same*as the starting pattern. This type of symmetry is called a**[translation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Translation_(geometry))**. Examples**A**and**C**are similar, except that the smallest possible shifts are in diagonal directions.
* If one*turns*example**B**clockwise by 90°, around the centre of one of the squares, again one obtains exactly the same pattern. This is called a**[rotation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotation)**. Examples**A**and**C**also have 90° rotations, although it requires a little more ingenuity to find the correct centre of rotation for**C**.
* One can also*flip*example**B**across a horizontal axis that runs across the middle of the image. This is called a**[reflection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reflection_(mathematics))**. Example**B**also has reflections across a vertical axis, and across two diagonal axes. The same can be said for**A**.
However, example**C**is*different*. It only has reflections in horizontal and vertical directions,*not*across diagonal axes. If one flips across a diagonal line, one does*not*get the same pattern back, but the original pattern shifted across by a certain distance. This is part of the reason that the wallpaper group of**A**and**B**is different from the wallpaper group of**C**.
Another transformation is a[glide reflection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glide_reflection), a combination of reflection and translation parallel to the line of reflection.
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/...

Symmetry
“A body is said to be symmetrical when it can be divided into parts that are related to each other in certain ways. The operation oftransferring one part to the position of a symmetrically related part is termed a symmetry operation, the result of which is to leave the final 
state of the body indistinguishable from its original state. In general, successive application of the symmetry operation must ultimatelybring the body actually into its original state again.”From: Lipson/Cochran, The Determination of Crystal Structures
Lipson, H., and W. Cochran. The Determination of Crystal Structures. Ithaca, NY: Cornell UniversityPress, 1966. ISBN: 080140276X.
Symmetry Operations
In two dimensions there are (besides identity): mirror, rotation, and glideThe symbol for the mirror is a solid line.
Figure by MIT OpenCourseWare.
Symmetry Operations
In two dimensions there are (besides identity): mirror, rotation, and glideThe symbol for the threefold is a triangle: (120° rotation)Twofold: Fourfold: Sixfold:180° rotation 90° rotation 60° rotation
Figure by MIT OpenCourseWare.
Symmetry Operations
In two dimensions there are (besides identity): mirror, rotation, and glideThe symbol for the glide is a dashed line.
Figure by MIT OpenCourseWare.
Symmetry plus Translation
“In a two-dimensional design, such as that of a wall-paper, a unit of pattern is repeated at regular intervals. Let us chose some representative point in the unit of pattern, and mark the position of similar points in all the other units. If these points be considered alone, the pattern being for the moment disregarded, it will be seen that they form a regular network. By drawing lines through them,
the 
area can be divided into a series of cells each of which contains a unit of the pattern. It is immaterial which point of the design is chosen as representative, for a similar n
etwork o
f points will always 
be obtained.”
Bragg, Sir Lawrence, et al. The Crystalline State, Volumes I-IV. Ithaca, NY: Cornell University Press, 1965.
Symmetry plus Translation

o.
Going 3D
In three dimensions we have additional symmetry operators: inversion centers and screw axes. In addition, the mirror becomes a mirrorplane, and the glides become glide planes.The inversion center can be understood as the intersection of a mirror and a twofold axis.Screw axes are like spiral staircases. The rotation is combined with a translation in a defined crystallographic direction by a defined step (half a unit cell for twofold screw axes, a third of a unit cell for threefold screw axes, etc.
Going 3D

* in plane
perpendicular to plane

Metric Symmetry of the Crystal Lattice
The metric symmetry is the symmetry of the crystal lattice without taking into account the arrangement of the atoms in the unit cell. In reciprocal space, this is equiv
alent to looking at the positions of 
the reflections without taking into account their relative intensities.There are 7 so called crystal systems (triclinic, monoclinic, orthorhombic, tetragonal, trigonal, hexagonal, and cubic). The rhombohedral system can be understood as a special case of the trigonal system, but some crystallographer count it as a separate crystal system.Taking into account possible lattice centerings, there are 14 so called Bravais lattices.
The 14 Bravais Lattices

Laue Symmetry
The Laue symmetry is the symmetry in reciprocal space (taking into 
account the reflex intensities). Friedel’s law is assumed to be true.The Laue symmetry can be lower than the highest metric symmetry (e.g. monoclinic with β = 90°), but never higher.

* DOI:[10.1103/PhysRevE.106.054603](https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.106.054603)
* Corpus ID: 250644318# Densest plane group packings of regular polygons.
```
@article{Torda2022DensestPG,
title={Densest plane group packings of regular polygons.},
author={Miloslav Torda and John Yannis Goulermas and Vitaliy Kurlin and Graeme M. Day},
journal={Physical review. E},
year={2022},
volume={106 5-1},
pages={
054603
},
url={https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:250644318}
}
```
* [M. Torda](https://www.semanticscholar.org/author/M.-Torda/51501948),[J. Y. Goulermas](https://www.semanticscholar.org/author/J.-Y.-Goulermas/1723263),+1 author[G. Day](https://www.semanticscholar.org/author/G.-Day/4889312)
* Publishedin[Physical Review E](https://www.semanticscholar.org/venue?name=Physical%20Review%20E)18 July 2022
* Mathematics
Packings of regular convex polygons (n-gons) that are sufficiently dense have been studied extensively in the context of modeling physical and biological systems as well as discrete and computational geometry. Former results were mainly regarding densest lattice or double-lattice configurations. Here we consider all two-dimensional crystallographic symmetry groups (plane groups) by restricting the configuration space of the general packing problem of congruent copies of a compact subset of the…Expand

results.text:
Wallpaper Groups -- from Wolfram MathWorld
![](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/images/header/menu-icon.png)TOPICS
[](https://www.wolfram.com/mathematica/)[](https://wolframalpha.com/)[](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/)[](https://www.wolfram.com/mathematica/)[](https://wolframalpha.com/)[](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/)![Search](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/images/header/search-icon.png "Search")![Close](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/images/header/menu-close.png "Close")
![](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/images/sidebar/menu-close.png)![Search](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/images/header/search-icon.png "Search")
# Wallpaper Groups
The wallpaper groups are the 17 possible plane[symmetry groups](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/SymmetryGroup.html). They are commonly represented using[Hermann-Mauguin](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/Hermann-MauguinSymbol.html)-like
symbols or in orbifold notation (Zwillinger 1995, p.260).
orbifold notation|[Hermann-Mauguin symbol](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/Hermann-MauguinSymbol.html)|
o|p1|
2222|p2|
\*\*|pm|
xx|pg|
\*2222|pmm|
22\*|pmg|
22x|pgg|
x\*|cm|
2\*22|cmm|
442|p4|
\*442|p4m|
4\*2|p4g|
333|p3|
\*333|p3ml|
3\*3|p3lm|
632|p6|
\*632|p6m|
![WallpaperGroups](images/eps-svg/WallpaperGroups_700.svg)
Patterns created with Artlandia SymmetryWorks for each of these groups are illustrated above.
![WallpaperGroupPatterns](images/eps-svg/WallpaperGroupPatterns_600.png)
Beautiful patterns can be created by repeating geometric and artistic motifs according to the symmetry of the wallpaper groups, as exemplified in works by M.C.Escher
and in the patterns created by I.Bakshee in the[Wolfram
Language](http://www.wolfram.com/language/)using Artlandia, illustrated above.
For a description of the symmetry elements present in each space group, see Coxeter (1969, p.413).
## See also
[Crystallographic Point Groups](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/CrystallographicPointGroups.html),[Space Groups](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/SpaceGroups.html),[Tessellation](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/Tessellation.html),[Tiling](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/Tiling.html)## Explore with Wolfram|Alpha
![WolframAlpha](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/images/wolframalpha/WA-logo.png "WolframAlpha")
More things to try:
* [finite groups](http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=finite+groups)
* [tiling](http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=tiling)
* [Wang's conjecture](http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=Wang's+conjecture)

](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1584882913/ref=nosim/ericstreasuretro)*> Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press, pp. 259-264, 1995.

results.title: Plane symmetry groups — ViPErLEED 1.0.0 documentation
results.text:
- [Background](https://www.viperleed.org/content/background.html)
- Plane symmetry groups
- [View page source](https://www.viperleed.org/_sources/content/background/planegroups.rst.txt)

[Previous](https://www.viperleed.org/content/background/tensor_leed.html) [Next](https://www.viperleed.org/content/viperleed_calc.html)

* * *

# Plane symmetry groups [](https://www.viperleed.org/content/background/planegroups.html\#plane-symmetry-groups)

The symmetry of crystal surfaces can be classified as one of 17 possible plane
symmetry groups (also sometimes referred to as “wallpaper groups”). For more
information, see, for example, the corresponding
[Wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_planar_symmetry_groups).

These groups are defined by the shape of the unit cell and by the symmetry
operations that leave the surface invariant: rotation axes, mirror planes,
and glide planes. [Fig. 2](https://www.viperleed.org/content/background/planegroups.html#fig-plane-groups), shows an overview of the 17
plane groups, allowed symmetry operations and possible subgroups. There,
an “×” indicates the point used by ViPErLEED as the conventional position
of the origin of the unit cell. See the relevant ViPErLEED publication for
more details \[ [3](https://www.viperleed.org/content/appendix/references.html#id3)\].

[![Overview of planegroups and possible symmetry operations.](https://www.viperleed.org/_images/PlaneGroups_embedded.svg)](https://www.viperleed.org/_images/PlaneGroups_embedded.svg)

Fig. 2 Overview of the 17 plane groups and possible symmetry operations. For each group, exemplary symmetry-equivalent atoms are shown as filled and empty circles in the left panel. The right panel shows the positions of the mirror, glide, and rotational symmetry elements. Symmetry elements drawn in red are related to those drawn in black via translations by integer multiples of the unit-cell vectors. Blue and black arrows in the left panels show examples of in-plane atomic displacements. Atoms linked by symmetry have symmetry-related displacements. Double arrows in groups pm, cm, and rcm indicate that movement is restricted along the mirror plane. Four-character plane-group designations are also indicated in gray, though ViPErLEED uses short forms in all input and output. Possible subgroups and additional notes are shown next to each group. [](https://www.viperleed.org/content/background/planegroups.html#id2)
